DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the border configuration of a tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to description of a tumor border.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An abnormal tissue growth resulted from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant ones exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: The boundary of a surface or object.:Description; a statement that represents something in words.

Concepts.definition: The boundary of a surface or object.
A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_The boundary of a surface or object._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

PermissibleValues.value: Unable to evaluate (tumor border not present on slide)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The boundary of a surface or object.: Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

Concepts.definition: The boundary of a surface or object.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act of applying force in order to move something away.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.: To draw a geometric figure around another figure so that the two are in contact but do not intersect.

Concepts.definition: The act of applying force in order to move something away.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
To draw a geometric figure around another figure so that the two are in contact but do not intersect.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:The boundary of a surface or object.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The boundary of a surface or object.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
